title: H.S. girls soccer: A bandaged Erica Bardes leads Pascack Hills
text:
Print 
MONTVALE – Watching Erica Bardes unwind after a soccer game is like witnessing a character from Stephen Crane’s "The Red Badge of Courage" as she takes off an assortment of compression bandages and athletic tape from her legs and upper torso. 
"I have hip and groin problems," said Bardes, a junior midfielder for the Pascack Hills girls soccer team. "It’s not too bad as long as it’s wrapped tight." 
Bardes’ litany of injuries were not an issue, especially when she made a pretty 360-degree spin move and uncorked a shot that made its way into the net for Pascack Hills’ 1-0 victory over Westwood on Monday. 
With the game winding down toward a possible scoreless deadlock between the rivals, Bardes collected the ball down the left flank in the 64th minute and began to weave her whirling magic, spinning and turning around and around — with the ball, no less — before firing the shot toward goal. 
"My idea was to get the ball in front to one of my teammates," Bardes said. "I tried to mix it up with my left foot and my right, and I just sort of turned. It just kind of went in." 
There were three Westwood defenders in front of the box, but the ball bounced its way in. 
"It feels pretty good," Bardes said. "Especially with the tough time I’ve had physically. This was pretty clutch. It definitely takes a lot of concentration to move with both feet, but I have to use the left side [because she’s naturally left-footed]. I was just able to fake them out and get to the ball." 
The victory improved Pascack Hills to 7-5-1, while Westwood dropped to 6-6-1. The teams played to a tie earlier this season. 
"It was a back-and-forth battle," Pascack Hills coach Scott Ernest said. "Erica is a difference-maker, making that play. She’s been doing that all season. Her timing here was phenomenal. We’re hoping that this gives us a home game in the states. We have to see." 
Pascack Hills received solid play offensively and defensively from junior midfielder Allison Ernest, the coach’s daughter. 
"She commands the middle of the field," Ernest said and joked, "and if she doesn’t do that, then I won’t feed her when we get home." 
The Cowgirls also were led by the play of junior goalkeeper Mackenzie Catherwood, who made six saves to earn the clean sheet, but none bigger than her final two of the day. 
Twice in the closing minutes, Westwood freshman forward Taylor Hirstius got behind the Pascack Hills’ back line to maneuver toward Catherwood. On one shot, Catherwood snared the ball between her legs. On the final shot of the game with two minutes left, Catherwood came out of goal to prevent a Hirstius breakaway. 
"She has done a phenomenal job for us," Ernest said of his goalie. "She did the right thing by coming out of the goal. She’s made all the right decisions for us." 
The Cowgirls had the better of the action, collecting 12 shots compared with seven for the Cardinals. 
"But we had quality chances," Westwood coach Eric Pfeifer said. "We just didn’t get that final touch. Taylor has been clutch for us. She’s just beginning to scratch the surface." 
The day belonged to the kid wearing the heavy bandages. 
"I guess this all works," Bardes said. © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
